Because whenever I’m brainstorming a vegetarian dinner party dish that won’t require a hundred sides, enchiladas is the answer. Stuffed with beans, greens, and cheese, they’re the all-in-one large format main that has it all. (Don’t worry, I will also make you guacamole.)But not all enchiladas are good enchiladas. What makes the difference? First and foremost, the sauce. All of the extremely opinionated BA food editors agree that the key to successful enchiladas is homemade sauce—and enough of it. In this recipe, the salsa verde is made in the oven: You’ll broil the vegetables (poblanos for smokiness, tomatillos for tang, jalapeños for heat) until they’re blackened, then blend them up (no chopping!) until you have a spicy, vibrant sauce. Taste it for salt! The sauce is the backbone of the whole dish—it coats every tortilla, it seasons the filling, it gets poured on top—so you’ll want to make sure it’s seasoned to your liking.Second, the filling. If vegetarian enchiladas are going to be a meal, there’s gotta be more than cheese and sauce in there. Even though this filling is super simple—sautéed onions and kale mixed with canned pinto beans (they get so creamy!) and a couple of charred poblanos that have been spared from the blender—it’s still green enough to pass for a real serving of vegetables. And because you don’t need to roast a chicken or braise short ribs, the filling comes together in fifteen minutes rather than three hours.Once you’ve got the sauce and the filling, all that’s left is the assembly. Enchiladas are an easy three-step process—dip tortilla in sauce, fill, and roll up and put in a baking dish (see this reference image for help)—unless the tortillas rip during the process, in which case it’s terribly frustrating and will feel like the end of the world*. If you’re using fresh, high-quality tortillas, warming them in a foil pouch in the oven (or individually on the stove) will reduce rippage. But if you’re working with the kinda hard, kinda dry, kinda stale tortillas that are common at grocery stores, I highly recommend a quick dip in a pan of hot olive oil (just 10 seconds per side) to make the tortillas pliable (you know, like they’ve just gone to hot yoga). They’ll also be richer, more flavorful, and more stable  when you cover them with sauce and cheese.If this feels like a lot for one day, split it up: Make the sauce and the filling two or three days in advance, then keep them in the fridge until it’s enchilada night. When your friends ask what they can bring for dinner, you can honestly tell them nothing. Enchiladas have it covered. (Though a bottle of wine would be nice.)*It is not the end of the world. You can either a) go take a walk and make your sous chef struggle through it, or b) just make a layered enchilada “casserole” situation: alternate layers of sauced-but-flat tortillas with layers of filling, then cover with sauce and bake.
